Pretty Mediocre Top Down Shooter   You play as Not Important, a man on a mission to kill everyone for no known reason. I'm not going to hold 'story' against this game because it's pretty clear it's not a story driven game. I will however point out that it's impossible to take this game seriously, and it feels like that's what they were going for. The fact that this is rated AO is an embarrassment to the ESRB. You're supposed to rate games on content, not the amount of political heat they draw.  The graphics are alright, but the game needs to find a better balance between 'grungy' and 'visible'. You'll have a lot of trouble on some levels even navigating around the level at all. The game does have an art style, if 'trying too hard: grunge edition' is an art style. Still, it  does  succeed somewhat at capturing the feel the game is going for. Occasionally walls won't render. That's the biggest graphical glitch I've come across so far.  The sound is alright. Decent quality. Not Important sounds like an emo grungy Xavier Renegade Angel. 3d sound glitches are plentiful, leading to the occasional random ear-bursting gunshot. You have a repertoire of about... 10 one liners from executions and that's it. Overall the sound is...  okay.   The gameplay is also okay. It's a standard top-down shooter. Healing mechanics can get frustrating, especially when you're facing down a wave of 60 cops and you need health. You have to execute to gain health which requires being right next to someone, so these stand-offs usually end up in you either dying if you come closer for health, or dying because you can't heal. Damned if you do, damned if you don't. Add onto that that there is no guaranteed execution and it can get really frustrating really fast, with you hoping that the game's Random Death Generator will be merciful enough to  not  insta-kill the guy you just punted with F, a maneuver the game's loading screens lead you to believe is a reliable method of lining up an execution.  Not Important really should have spent some time at the shooting range before going on his shooting rampage, because he can't aim for ♥♥♥♥. You'll spend a lot of time frustrated at how much you  don't  hit ♥♥♥♥ you're aiming at. The aiming system either rarely compensates for height difference, or doesn't at all. I never caught it doing so for the two hours I played. Granted, the level designs usually render this mostly a non-issue, but for the rare case it's another point of extreme frustration. Not Important really should have also hit the gym, because he can't throw for ♥♥♥♥ either. Grenades almost always make it about 60% of the way to your crosshair. Where they go when you throw them is also almost impossible to predict. I gave up on my strategy of throwing them through doorways to soften the resistance before I entered a room the third time in a row Not Important threw the grenade right into the doorframe and blew himself up.  Respawn tokens are a pain in the ♥♥♥. You don't recover the respawn tokens you had at the start of a level upon restarting the level. This basically ensures that the level will only get  harder  if you lose at it. Another ingredient for our recipe of annoying, frustrating time. Cop and SWAT cars are OP as all ♥♥♥♥. They will swoop in and run you over before you have any time to react, and every time a car hits you, it's a one hit kill. They will not wait for you to finish an execution either, I executed someone to find myself already run over by a SWAT car by the time the execution scene was done happening.   Overall, Hatred isn't really a  bad  game, but it's not a  good  game either. It's also not a game I'd actually recommend for $20.

If Hatred was more fully devoted to being either a comedy or a drama, its narrative may have been more successful. As it is, the most fun to be had in the game comes almost entirely from the moments when the player breaks away from the mission structure and massacre everyone around without worrying about the context of its plot.  The game only has 7 parts but all of them offer great replay value.  The highlight of this game is mostly due to itself being very realistic. What I meant by realistic is that the AI in-game actually act like how real people do in the real world. The female AI of this game often tends to run away instead of fighting back even though they are brave feminists. The protecting forces of the game which consist of police offers, the SWAT team and also the army are all male, and never a single female, leaving all the men to die on their own. Just like in real life! Has it ever occurred to anyone that the engineer at the ending was a male instead of a female? Shocking truth!  What the game lacks is diversity. Every single one of the civilians that you can kill in game are mostly normal citizens with no special traits aside from the difference in their skin color. To make the game as realistic as possible, the developers should have added AI like feminists or Social Justice Warriors like what Postal did. Besides that, there should also be gays and lesbians making out on the street. This should have already been implemented with no question ask since hipsters and drug junkies have existed in game.   The achievements created in this game are quite interesting as they contain references to other games such as Grand Theft Auto, Postal and the Witcher series. As you can see on my profile’s achievement page, I have gotten nearly every single Hatred’s achievement, they are really easy to accomplish and are able to be unlocked from time to time as you progress in game. The only achievement which I am having trouble unlocking is the one called “Feminist”. The objective to unlocking it is to kill 2000 men if I recall correctly. But sadly, I only shoot women. Due to this tough obstacle, I am unable to 100% the game. So I do hope they do something about it in the future as this achievement would also mark me as a feminist which I am not.   The game itself is not flawless but it clearly shows a promising future for a genre more like it to be produced and also be able to offer a lot of fun. Without a doubt this is the best open world shooting game in recent years. 9.5/10

So, Hatred. I stumbled upon this game having never heard of it before. The title is what reeled me, and the fact that it was at the top of Steam. I checked it out quickly. I love a game that flips common tropes on their head and is not afraid to push the envelope to the point of breaking. The fact that this is basically a mass-murder simulator when (in the US at least) there are mass shootings every day really gave this game a lot of 'edge' for lack of a better term, which is what I like in games, whether that edge be due to controversy, difficulty, or in depth storylines. However, it is rare to find raw unadulterated controversial gore nowadays. I decided, despite the negative reviews to buy this game at its current price and play it.   Pay no mind to the negative reviews, this game is amazing. The black-and-white artstyle is amazing, the voice acting is amazing, the weapons, environments, enemies, civilians, executions, all contribute to a fun violence simulator. It is simple, easy to play, enjoyable in its brutality whilst still being challenging to the point of me damn near throwing a tantrum over losing a level 5 TIMES! The best part is, the developers and the game make no bones about what this game is: a mass-murder simulator, designed to simply and brutally explore in an arcade-like manner, the activities of a violent misanthrope bent on killing anyone in his path. Its simple, brutal, and violent, which is something that seems rare in today's gaming environment.  For god's sake even the credits are a heavy-metal music video of gore and death, showing the main character brutally killing both police and civilians alike.   It makes a good stress reliever, a good arcade shooter, and just a good game overall with great style and flow in the gameplay. 10/10

Hatred is a top-down twin stick shooter where your goal is to kill everybody that moves. The game takes place over 7 distinct areas where you can free-roam (for the most part) and do objectives as you wish. The game does have requirements to move on to the next stage, mainly 'Kill X amount of people' or 'Get out of X'. There are several side objectives that mostly involve killing the majority of people in a given area. Completing these side objectives gives you respawn tokens to use if you die. If you die and you're out of respawns, you have to restart the level.  You yourself play as an edgy misanthrope who has long hair, wears a black trench coat, and spouts one-liners. You are controlled with WASD by default, and there is a sprint mechanic that you can use to vault over small walls, a crouch mechanic that makes you harder to hit and increases your aim, an aiming mechanic that allows you to precisely aim as well as aim higher or lower to compensate for the top-down nature, and this spidey-sense type mechanic that highlights living enemies on your screen as well as equipment pickups. You can carry up to three weapons at a time, from about 10 weapons There is a health system, where you can only regenerate a bit of health by executing 'not-quite-dead' enemies. It sounds all horrible, but trust me, you get used to the same 'stomp the guys head in' or 'shoot the guy in the head' animation after a hundred times. The player character does sometimes get caught on hard-to-see level geometry or a tiny chip of a wall still standing which can be pretty irksome if you're trying to get away from a firefight.  You aren't just shooting innocent civilians, you'll be fighting police, weapons dealers, vigilantes, hunters, SWAT, and the army. Even unarmed civilians will sometimes pick up a gun and start unloading on you. They aren't pushovers, either. On higher difficulties, SWAT can take three shots with a shotgun and still be standing, and you'll often be forced to retreat and find some civvies to execute. The AI has a lot of room for improvement, but I let it slide because it's not really something you ask for in an indie game. An annoying features is that enemies can shoot you from beyond your maximum view range, forcing you to rely on your (inconsistent) minimap to find your shooter.  The gunplay is solid and even the 9mm pistol manages to actually do something rather just being the equivalent of spitballs against tougher enemies. The physics engine is great and it's a lot of fun to play around with, though it can be pretty CPU-intensive. Speaking of graphics, I'm a fan of the style, where everything is grayscale except red, blue, and explosions. It can give me a headache playing too long, though.  It's a pretty short game, I beat it on hard in 3 hours, but like I said, they're free-roam areas and I was mostly just rushing objectives. Unless you want to screw around with the levels you liked later or get achievements, it's not a game that you'll replay a lot. There is workshop support and multiplayer/coop planned down the road, which would add a breath of fresh air to the game.  Finally, the moral panic. The game is not a fourth as bad as the trailers made it out to be. It's actually pretty tame. Like I said, you get jaded to the executions, and there's not really a lot of over-the-top gore except for bloodstains, blood pools, and some limb removal. I honestly don't see how this got an AO rating, it's M at best. For the tone, it gets pretty clear the game is parodying itself. The over-the-top one-liners by the player character (who is called the Antagonist by the developers) includes a line from the POSTAL DUDE. An important code for something later in the game is 666, for god's sake. Don't be offended.  Overall, I'd give it a 6.5/10, above average. Make sure you buy the game if you like it, not just to stick it to the people who don't like it.

The game that Simpsons and the like parodied in the nineties after Mortal Kombat and such came out.  This is the game that all the hysterical parents didn't want their kids to play: a murder simulator, full of blood, gore, and mindless ultra violence, made with the intent of corrupting the young. Except it's not.  It's a goofy, over the top look into the minds of angst ridden kids who write misanthropic poems in their bedrooms, walls plastered with posters of extreme metal bands and drawings of satanic symbols, while hate filled music made by grown men wearing clothes either from a military surplus store or the hot topic.  It's a dumb game, but it's also a very fun game (when it isn't keyboard and mouse throwing out the window frustrating). It's fun because it allows you to do what every single one of us have wanted to do when we get bullied at school, fired from work or when a car drives by, hits a puddle and splashes water all over you ruining your brand new clothes. The equivalent of sitting down and smoking a sub-par joint but everywhere else is dry.  Hatred takes place in the outskirts of New York City, where you play as an unnamed man named The Antagonist (DID YOU SEE WHAT WE DID THERE?!). As the Antagonist, your goal is to murder as many human beings as possible, be it by fire, firearms, knife, grenade, or old fashioned curb stomping and kicks to the head.  The gameplay itself is below average. The controls are functional, but it runs into the Assassin's Creed problem of being able to run into walls very easily. Hit detection can be a bit dodgy as well, and it is entirely possible to fire a shotgun point blank and miss due to visual difficulties.  Which ramroads us to the next point in the visuals. Thematically, it's presented a bit like Sin City: all dismal greys and blacks and whites with some splashes of Red for blood or Blue for police lights. Your crosshairs can be different colours as well (which is hilarious when its green), but even then it's difficult to tell at the best of times where you, or anyone else, currently is, or what's hitting you to begin with.  The weapons are satisfying enough. You point guns in one direction, bullets fly out of them, and they interact with civillians in obvious ways. AI's dodgy though, so more often than not you have policemen completely missing where you are and civillians who run screaming -towards- you, for some reason.   Despite this, Hatred is fun in the sense that you are not playing it to beat it, nor are you playing it for a good story experience (especially not that, dear god the acting...). You're playing it because Dave at work flipped all your buttons, Sasha was able to emasculate you at the company meeting that day, and Darryl was busy being Darryl, the self centered idiot. So, you come home, flick on this murder simulator, and just blank out for a few minutes.  Hatred is a game that exists to unjudgementally help you relax and unwind after a long day until you're ready to do something productive, like playing a far, far better game. Postal 2, the GTA series 3 and onwards, Manhunt 2, they all accomplish Hatred's job better than it does. But Hatred itself accomplishes what it set out to do regardless; here is you, here are some guns, here are people who can be shot, go have fun.  Maybe get it on sale, but I'm not upset at paying ~20$ for this.

I beat the game on hard. It took 7 hours. It wasn't easy. I don't think it was a shallow shooting game by any means. The system of executing people for health is conceptually silly but it leads to some tense gameplay later in the game when almost everyone has a gun.   Levels are large and have interesting layouts and options for cover. I've seen some reviews say that cover in this game doesn't work and this is just a twin stick shooter, but in the later parts of the game you won't do too well without crouching behind everything you can. When it gets harder it almost becomes an overhead cover shooter if you are playing it right.   The destruction is the coolest looking feature and probably one of the coolest gameplay elements. Being able to make the cops/army trap you in a corner, just to blow an escape hole with a grenade, and then flank your pursuers through a window makes this a more interesting affair than just popping out from behind corners all day long. Grenades are plentiful for about half the game, too, so there is a lot of opportity to make rubble.  One thing I think is odd that people aren't really mentioning is that this is basically an exact remake of the original POSTAL. Not all of the levels are the same, but they both feature a similar perspective, a main character in a duster, a mission to murder everyone and nothing more, similar weapons, half dead enemies crawling on the ground and struggling to breathe and gurgling blood, and they both start out at the main characters house.   Only complaints are the camera makes it so that it's always easier to go north, but some levels make you come back south, forcing you to use different tactics just because your view isn't as good. The game is a little short at 7 hours, but not bad for the price. It was a crazy fun 7 hours, though. And the black and white is kind of blah, I wish there was a cheat for color.  If you enjoyed the original POSTAL, or Crusader: No R---- games, then you'll understand the minor control issues here and probably love this game. Or if you just like really awesome looking destructive violence.

As its core, Hatred is an interesting game because it reminds us how narrow, formulaic and claustrophobic gaming narratives can be. Imagine cinema without Scarface, Hannibal Lecter or even Mike Leigh's Johnny. Moral ambiguity is essential to the silver screen but remains only a distant hope on our monitors.   The game certainly has its limitations. The core mechanics are those of a middling-quality isometric shooter with some fine destruction physics. Moreover, no significant narrative is provided for the orgy of destruction. This could either be viewed as serving the nihilistic atmosphere, or be considered as a narrative failing when compared to cinematic anti-heroes.   However, considering that the utterances of Hatred's anti-hero are not especially inspired, it's perhaps for the better than the minimalistic approach has been taken - we are free to each craft our own reasons for the violence.  Positives:  - Good atmosphere; cold, grim visuals - Surprisingly good physics & destruction via UE4. It works well when backed into an Apple Store's bathroom and gunning down soldiers, who finally bring the entire structure down, forcing a hasty run-and-gun exit through the rubble. - Good concept - One of the best flamethrowers since Return To Castle Wolfenstein.  Negatives:  - For a game so rooted in gunplay, the actual gun sounds lack punch. - Something of a manufactured controversy - not really as violent or drastic as people might expect, - A fundamentally simple game that would struggle to justify a higher price point.

That said, at its core it's a pretty fun twin stick shooter. When it's time to deal with some actual threats the game's actually pretty challenging and rewarding. Ducking, dodging, and generally evading gunfire is pretty intense and the guns themselves feel like they have a proper oomph behind them.   The destructable environments lend a lot to that effect as well when desks, glass, thin walls, and just about anything in the level really is destroyed and blown up by gunfire and explosions. The destructable environments themselves also allow for some creative approaches to combat as well. SWAT team swarming the house you're holed up in and you need a quick way out? Shoot the conveniently placed oxygen canister in the garage to blow a hole in the side of the building to flee through. Need to clear out a heavily fortified building but can't get through the front door without getting mowed down? Steal a SWAT van and drive it through the side of the building.   That said, it's not without its faults. The driving mechanics feel extremely clunky and sometimes it's easy to glitch the vehicles out on the geometry in really weird ways. I mentioned before that just about anything in the level can be destroyed. Well the game can be pretty stupid at times about what qualifies as just about anything. It's pretty silly when you can ram an armored van straight through the side of a solid concrete building but at the same time it just stops dead in its tracks when it hits a chest high brick wall. The monochrome color scheme can be a pain in the ♥♥♥ at times as well. A good example would be the sewer level where it makes it extremely difficult to tell whats blocking your path and what isn't, which makes it fairly easy to get caught on the terrain during a firefight or duck behind what you might think is a pipe running along the floor only to realize after taking two shells in the chest is actually an overhanging pipe.  Overall though, while the premise behind the game might be understandably off putting to people the core mechanics themselves are pretty great. If nothing else, it'd be pretty cool to see what the developers could do with it outside of a mass murder simulator.

First off, I have to say that my ultimate feelings on the game are... It's boring.  A lot of people have likened this game to a modern remake of the original problem. Here's the big problem with that notion. Postal offered a legitamite challenge to the player. There were varied forms of opposition, and a genuine challenge from level to level, and if you kept track of the journal entries of the character that were in the manual, there was a story about a man who was truly snapped in half. The reality of your actions in the game do not match the journal entries in the manual. You truly got more out of the experience than something like Hatred gives you.  Hatred has you playing a parody of a mass murderer. You go around shooting people. Then you do it again, and again, and again. Now, many will ask how that's any different from a game like Doom? Well, again, there's variety there. Different enemy types, and you're not *just* shooting things in a game like Doom. You're exploring a maze, you're tracking down key cards, or solving the hostility found within environments. Hatred doesn't have that. The only progression to be found in the game is that you go from completely unarmed civilians, to regular cops, to SWAT team guys, to soldiers. They're a little tougher. Ultimatel you're just slaughtering unarmed people with devastating firepower. It get's old fast.  My personal reccomendation? Buy Postal, Postal 2, and it's new DLC 'Paradise Lost' you'll have far more fun that way.

The art style leaves much of the game obscured and difficult to make out, occasionally The Antagonist seems to forget what grenades are and the words uttered after the (quickly repetitive and dull) executions are laughable, if never quite as bad as, say, Spill The Dirty Blood Of Jesus.  I *do* recommend this game, as I'll likely play a lot more (I'm hoping for some patches and performance improvements) and in my own brief correspondence with the team responsible they seem like decent guys, even if they hadn't heard any Deathspell Omega.   Put quite simply, if you're 14, have greasy hair and think Cannibal Corpse are the greatest death metal band in the world, this is likely to be your favourite game. For the rest of us, it's a broken but daft mess that will raise a chuckle in the same way a Troma movie or Rompeprop CD will. Take it for what it is, don't expect to be hugely impressed, and have fun!  Oh, and for a twin-stick shooter it's *abysmal* to play with a controller, which is unforgivable. I'll personally fight the next person who compares this favourably with Robotron...

In real life, I'm a nice guy. I show others respect and consideration. I would never think of hurting someone unless it was to stop them from hurting myself or someone I care about. That being said, within the parameters of a videogame, I can be quite vicious. Vicious enough to thoroughly enjoy Running with Scissors' original game 'Postal', which made its debut in 1997. The expansion pack which followed, in addition to the sequels, were crippled with elements of self awareness and parody, turning it into a joke which paled in comparison to the bleak, nihilistic mindset of the original. About a year ago, I wrote Running with Scissors urging consideration of a remake, one that recaptured the initial vision with modern cutting edge graphics. I seriously doubted that such a remake would ever be in the making. Much has changed since 1997, a year in which most people had never even heard of Columbine.   Now, I'm nowhere egocentric enough to think that someone acted on this letter, but it's a good illustration of how others were having similar ideas. The result is Hatred, and it's a spiritual sequel to Postal. Right down to the anonymous maniac, the isometric perspective, and the executions. In many ways, the game surpasses Postal in brutality. For instance, first aid kits are nowhere to be found. The only way to replenish health is to execute victims writhing in pain on the ground. And while Postal kept the three-quarter perspective for an execution burst of gunfire to the head, Hatred switches to a close-up sequence in which your character will randomly act on a wide range of gruesome options. You can commandeer vehicles, kick in doors for a home invasion, and inflict a wide variety of damage to the surrounding environment. Perhaps the most effective decision in game design involved the use of color. Or rather, the lack of it. In a nod to Sin City, the world of Hatred is in black and white. The only color seen is linked to destructive acts: a fire, an explosion, a spray of blood. This has the effect of making the violence all the more striking. Simply put, Hatred is the Postal successor that Running with Scissors either could not or would not make. It surpasses it in almost every way.  Almost every way. And there lies the flaw of this potentially good game, at least if you're planning on playing with a mouse and keyboard. I haven't tried it yet on a twin stick gamepad. Here's the problem. In Postal, I would link my left and right strafing ability to the keyboard. My other hand would be controlling the mouse, where forward and backward motion were linked to the middle and right buttons. Actually moving the mouse from side to side would cause the character to turn in a 360 degree spin. Wherever your character would be facing when you stopped the spin determined the direction of your next action, whether it be forward, backward, or a strafe.   In Hatred, movement of the mouse likewise turns your character. However, the direction your character is facing does not determine the direction you will actually take when you move. Instead, forward is always going to take you to the top of the screen, backwards towards the bottom of the screen, strafing to the left and right. This... is... CONFUSING. I'm still attempting to get used to it. Perhaps I will. And to be fair, it makes some new moves possible, such as the ability to move and spin simultaneously while firing. Ultimately, however, this one factor ruins the game. Game control should be intuitive. Not so here. It's a mess. It took me thirty minutes before I finally managed to maneuver my way through the tutorial. Too bad. And over something so simple. Forewarning: I have not yet beaten this game. If you think that discredits my opinion on this title, feel free to stop reading at any point.  Anyone still here: Hatred, as most Steam users probably know, is a highly controversial isometric twin-stick shooter with a unique Sin City-inspired visual design that has garnered far more attention for its tangles with the ESRB and Steam, as well as its content, than it has for its merits as a game. So, how is it as a game?  To be fair, this isn't my normal kind of game. I don't play many twin-stick shooters, so I'm fairly new at this type of thing. I am also primarily a console gamer--I play on both Playstation and Xbox, with my laptop mainly being used for listening to music and playing Rollercoaster Tycoon. So I'm approaching this green as can be--I'm a filthy console gamer new to PC, I'm not much into twin-stick shooters, and my Steam account is brand-spanking new. Take everything I say with a grain, nay, a ♥♥♥♥ing barrel of salt.  I like it.  With a concept like the one Hatred carries around, this was always going to attract criticism, something the developers obviously knew. You play as The Antagonist, a man who hates the world and all people in it, probably including himself, and the object of most levels is to flat-out murder as many innocent civilians as possible. The effect is initially somewhat shocking, even knowing what this game is ahead of time. Following the tutorial, when The Antagonist takes his first steps out into his neighborhood and starts firing rounds, it definitely got me a bit 'oh, ♥♥♥♥...'  That all said though, this game isn't nearly as nefarious as people have made it out to be. It's CLEARLY tongue in cheek, unless you're deliberately fighting that aspect. The game's tutorial made me laugh out loud, instructing you on how to move around, jump over obstacles, shoot at targets and throw grenades....and then, before you leave the tutorial basement, you're instructed, in a very videogame way, to 'kill your drugged captive'. I snorted, it was so genius. Also adding to the tongue in cheek feel, your protagonist looks and talks like Nathan Explosion went to emo school, constantly growling lines like 'And who ♥♥♥♥ing cares?' and, even better, 'Only my weapons understand me.'  In terms of gameplay, things are fine, if a bit standard. Weapons feel good, aiming feels good, etc. One thing Destructive Creations should have improved is doorway entry; The Antagonist definitely likes to get hung up on doors. Also, and this is a frankly unacceptable oversight, this is a largely black and white game where your target reticle is white. So it's FAR too easy to lose sight of your reticle during, say, a hectic fight with the military. Why they didn't make it red, I'm not sure, but they didn't, and it's just a silly thing that causes way more frustration than necessary.  Though I imagine most probably don't care about the story in a game like this, I feel like I should say it's fairly toss. It's basically a thin string of events to tie the levels together. That's fine, to be honest. It means we never learn much about The Antagonist, and that's really for the better, since if this guy was anything more than a charicature, it would probably become too silly.  So basically: this is a short, fun game with a brilliant art style and some minor gameplay flaws. I got it on sale for $11, and I'm satisfied with it for that price. I may not have been at $20, but I suppose it depends on your genre preferences. People need to lighten up. The developers of this game clearly knew what they were doing, and the tongue-in-cheek nature demonstrates that every step of the way. Check it out if you're into this sort of thing, or even if you just want to see what all the fuss was about.  7/10  Two side notes: If you are a fan of death metal, it would appear the developers are as well--I'm not sure of the specifics, but apparently they set up some sort of show with the band Decapitated, and if you're a metal fan, it's always worth supporting the community, so thanks to the developers there.  Also, on a downer--the game appears to be fairly poorly optimized. Granted, my laptop isn't the greatest, but this is really kind of a crapshoot. Sometimes the game runs absolutely flawlessly, other times it's borderline unplayable. This seems to have nothing to do with specific levels or activities. Just a note.
